title: Famous Inventions & Inventors
description: Test your knowledge of groundbreaking inventions and the brilliant minds behind them.

questions.question: Who is credited with inventing the telephone in 1876?
questions.explanation: Alexander Graham Bell was awarded the first patent for the telephone in 1876, though others like Elisha Gray were working on similar devices.

questions.question: What did Johannes Gutenberg invent around 1440 that revolutionized communication?
questions.explanation: Gutenberg's movable-type printing press made books affordable and accessible, sparking a revolution in literacy and knowledge sharing.

questions.question: Who invented the World Wide Web in 1989?
questions.explanation: Tim Berners-Lee, a British scientist at CERN, invented the World Wide Web, creating HTML, URLs, and HTTP.

questions.question: What everyday item did Percy Spencer accidentally invent after noticing a chocolate bar melting in his pocket?
questions.explanation: In 1945, Percy Spencer was working with radar equipment when he noticed a chocolate bar had melted, leading to the invention of the microwave oven.

questions.question: Who is credited with inventing the first practical light bulb?
questions.explanation: While others created earlier versions, Thomas Edison developed the first commercially practical incandescent light bulb in 1879.

questions.question: The Wright Brothers made their famous first powered flight in which year?
questions.explanation: Orville and Wilbur Wright achieved the first sustained, controlled, powered flight on December 17, 1903, at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.

questions.question: What life-saving medicine did Alexander Fleming discover in 1928?
questions.explanation: Fleming discovered penicillin when he noticed mold killing bacteria in a petri dish, leading to the first antibiotic and saving millions of lives.

questions.question: Who invented the cotton gin in 1793?
questions.explanation: Eli Whitney's cotton gin mechanized the process of separating cotton fibers from seeds, dramatically increasing cotton production.

questions.question: What did Nikola Tesla primarily champion that now powers most of the world?
questions.explanation: Tesla championed alternating current (AC) electrical systems, which proved more efficient for long-distance power transmission than Edison's DC system.

questions.question: Who invented the first successful vaccine, and what disease did it target?
questions.explanation: Edward Jenner created the first vaccine in 1796 using cowpox to immunize against smallpox, pioneering the field of immunology.

questions.question: What communication device did Samuel Morse help develop in the 1830s?
questions.explanation: Samuel Morse co-developed the electric telegraph and created Morse code, revolutionizing long-distance communication.

questions.question: Who invented dynamite in 1867?
questions.explanation: Alfred Nobel invented dynamite and later used his fortune to establish the Nobel Prizes, perhaps as a way to leave a more positive legacy.

questions.question: What did Louis Braille invent in 1824 at the age of 15?
options: A reading system for the blind
questions.explanation: Louis Braille, who was blind himself, created the Braille system of raised dots that allows blind people to read and write.

questions.question: Who is credited with inventing the first practical sewing machine?
questions.explanation: Elias Howe patented the first practical sewing machine in 1846, using a lockstitch design. Isaac Singer later improved and popularized it.

questions.question: What did George Washington Carver famously develop hundreds of uses for?
questions.explanation: George Washington Carver developed over 300 products from peanuts, including dyes, plastics, and fuel, promoting agricultural diversity in the South.

questions.question: Who invented the phonograph, the first device to record and play back sound?
questions.explanation: Thomas Edison invented the phonograph in 1877. His first recording was 'Mary Had a Little Lamb.'

questions.question: What material did Charles Goodyear discover how to vulcanize in 1839?
questions.explanation: Goodyear discovered that heating rubber with sulfur made it durable and elastic, a process called vulcanization that made rubber commercially useful.

questions.question: Who invented the first practical zipper?
questions.explanation: Swedish-American Gideon Sundback designed the modern zipper in 1913, improving on earlier 'clasp locker' designs.

questions.question: What household appliance did James Dyson reinvent using cyclone technology?
questions.explanation: James Dyson created the first bagless vacuum cleaner using cyclonic separation in 1983, after 5,127 prototypes.

questions.question: Who invented the safety elevator, making tall buildings practical?
questions.explanation: Elisha Otis invented the safety elevator in 1852, with a mechanism to prevent the car from falling if the cable broke, making skyscrapers possible.
